subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
We're going to explore the shadow side of ayahuasca today.
With me is Dr. Rachel Harris, who is the author of
Listening to Ayahuasca, New Hope for Depression, Addiction, PTSD and Anxiety.
Dr. Harris is a psychologist. Welcome, Rachel.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
Pleasure to be with you again.
As a psychologist, we're always interested in the shadow side of human relationships.
That's where growth really occurs, is when people begin to confront their own shadow,
their own darkness, their fears in particular,
their propensities for anger and lust.
The whole negative side of human experience is very,
very fertile ground for growth of a psychological nature.
That's true with or without psychedelic drugs.
Absolutely. Yes.
In writing this book, one of the writings that I relied on was Anne Shulkin.
She's the wife of Sasha Shulkin.
Before ecstasy or MDMA became illegal, she was a lay psychotherapist using MDMA.
She's now in her 80s. She was a natural therapist.
She had a five-page paper, but it really
captured the value of this kind of psychotherapy.
I think she called it maybe encountering the shadow or something like that.
One of her warnings that was really interesting was unless
the therapist has really worked with their own shadow
and found a way to live with it and accept it and
be in relationship to the therapist's own shadow,
then they have no business working in this area
where in any of the psychedelics, the shadow arises.
If the therapist has not done their own work, they really
cannot work with a client encountering their shadow.
I thought she had some very important therapeutic
wisdoms to share, and that was one of them.
When we talk about the shadow side of ayahuasca,
part of that is people encountering their own shadow
as part of turning the microscope inward, so to speak.
But there are also other things that the shadow side of ayahuasca might refer to.
Yes, absolutely. There are real risks, and not
every shaman, I mean some shaman who supposedly,
if they have not completed their training,
which can go on for at least seven to 20 years,
I mean it goes on forever, they can be a brujo, a witch basically,
which means that they have attained some powers using ayahuasca and other medicines,
but they use them for their own self-interest.
So for instance, there have been reports of rapes in retreat centers in Peru,
where people have been, I mean it's sort of an old story,
the shaman mixed in datura, or toe, into the
ayahuasca mixture, and that is a dissociative drug,
and women get sort of knocked out and they
don't kind of know what's happening to them.
It can be a poison.
It can be a poison, it's a very dangerous drug,
and it practically functions like a rape drug,
and so women have been raped during these ayahuasca retreats.
So there's always that shadow side to a so-called spiritual teacher,
shaman don't even say that they're a spiritual teacher,
but anyone that someone is following for spiritual purposes,
there can always be that risk, whether it's about money or sex or power,
there's always that shadow side.
And another potential risk that you refer to is cultural appropriation.
Now that so many Westerners are traveling into the Amazon region,
or shamans are coming up from the Amazon, or Westerners are purporting to be shamans,
or have been initiated as shamans,
you have this cultural fusion taking place.
Right. I saw an ad where you can go to a retreat
center in Peru in six weeks and train to be a shaman.
Well, you know, the shaman who I know, it's decades of training.
So to say you can do this in six weeks is a good example of cultural appropriation.
To a certain extent, I have to say that
using this medicine for therapeutic purposes
could also be considered cultural appropriation.
I mean, the therapeutic purposes are clearly defined in a Western culture,
and that's not the indigenous use of this medicine exactly,
because they don't see things the same way.
They see any disturbances or symptoms as a soul problem,
that there's a spiritual problem that needs to be cured,
which is a very different perspective than a Western psychotherapeutic one.
So I'm also stretching the way the medicine can be used.
Well, to begin with, for the most part, as I understand it,
ayahuasca, unlike other psychedelics, is
pretty much always taken in a ritual context.
Yes. Yes. It certainly is not going to be a recreational substance,
because it's just too uncomfortable and not fun,
and people need a bathroom very close by.
So people are not going to do this at raves or music festivals,
where bathrooms are few and far between.
So some of the risks entail, has the ritual been properly prepared?
You know, this is really an important question.
I write in the book about the importance of the songs that the shaman sings.
They're called Ikaros.
And from an indigenous perspective, these songs are also the medicine.
And it's been said that if you really know the songs,
you don't even have to drink the medicine.
So I had somebody talk about a ceremony where they were,
and I said, and who was the shaman for the ceremony?
Well, we didn't really have a shaman.
We sort of had a DJ. He played music.
And I sort of want to tear my hair out.
That's only a part of what a legitimate ceremony is.
So they're missing all these other worlds that come together to make a full ritual.
And I think we, in the West, we would do well
to really respect the wholeness of this ritual.
But already we're not doing a good job at that,
because people can make money leading ceremonies.
And so that's always a problem.
Well, and that's part of our Western model.
The West, yes, the Western model.
The business model.
Yes, entrepreneurs.
Entrepreneurs, exactly, which I had many years
ago in Ayahuasca experience here in Nevada.
And it was like that.
There was a Western representative of the Santo Daime Church who had a tape
and played music during the experience.
My experience was completely positive, but I had no desire to return.
Right.
You know, once was enough.
Yes, I understand completely.
And it seems as if that's where we're taking
something which is sacred to the natives
who developed this tradition.
And we introduce money.
We introduce the idea of people gathering in a social context.
Oh dear.
I really want to pay respect to the integrity of a ritual ceremony
where the shaman is really trained.
And they choose what songs to sing depending on what's happening in the room.
They're sort of like a traffic controller.
They can see and sense what's going on.
Even though everybody's sitting in the dark and it's still and quiet,
I've experienced it that they can direct songs to specific people
and offer help through the singing.
And it's really, I hate to see the rituals become less than it can possibly be.
And the artwork too, they are also embodiments of the medicine.
You get a sense of how the culture fits together with this medicine
so that everything comes together in a ritual.
And I don't want us to lose that experience of the wholeness of a ritual.
But simply by bringing ayahuasca out of the jungle and taking it to North America,
and I wouldn't be surprised if today, this very day,
there are maybe a thousand different ceremonies
in North America involving ayahuasca.
That could be the case.
It's out.
It's out.
Right.
The genie is out of the bottle.
Exactly.
So maybe all I can do is say there is a wholeness to the ceremony
that we should at least know about and respect.
Because there is no control over who's leading ceremonies or where or how.
One of the things that I understand from reading your book
is that it's almost impossible to overdose on ayahuasca.
Yes.
People will vomit the medicine up.
So the risk is the serotonin syndrome that I mentioned before.
But people won't overdose.
And there's no addiction risk either.
No, we haven't really gone into the serotonin syndrome.
Let's discuss that.
What's tricky about that is that one of the
symptoms is too much serotonin in the system.
And this happens if you're taking antidepressants and you take a psychedelic.
This warning is good for all the psychedelics.
One of the symptoms is that you vomit.
So how would anybody in a ceremony know?
Are you vomiting because it's the ayahuasca vomiting?
Are you vomiting because there's too much serotonin in your system?
How would we differentiate?
It's very difficult.
And let's talk about this.
I know that we know very little about the actual
biochemistry of ayahuasca and other psychedelics.
But my basic understanding for a long time has been what you reported in the book
that the drug or medicine seems to replace
serotonin in the serotonin receptors of the brain.
Yes, you end up with more serotonin in your system and in your gut as well.
That's part of the vomiting.
And it's also part of people the next day feel great, usually.
And it's because they've gotten a real boost to their serotonin.
And when they measure it, they find that that boost lasts for two to four weeks.
And coincidentally, the churches who drink this medicine as part of their sacrament,
they often have ceremonies every two to four weeks.
So they know how to keep this in the system.
Following the natural cycle.
Right. It makes complete sense.
And serotonin normally is something of a neural inhibitor, as I recall.
So when the drug or medicine is replacing serotonin in the neural receptors,
that would suggest that the nervous system itself is being disinhibited.
I don't have that level of expertise to answer that.
But what I can say is they have put...
IOWASC is similar enough to the other psychedelics
that I drew on research with psilocybin, the chemical and magic mushrooms.
And they somehow managed to give people psilocybin
and put them in a functional MRI machine.
And when they do that, the functional MRI shows less blood flow
to what they call the default mode network.
That is not an anatomical part of the brain.
It's a neurological network that goes throughout the brain.
And the researcher in England said it pretty much is the system
that supports our sense of ego, our sense of self.
So it's this kind of running commentary inside of us.
You know, when we're driving and we're just ruminating.
Or we're driving ourselves crazy with self-criticism.
This default mode network accounts for about half of our inner monologue.
And it supports our consensus reality, how we see things,
how we're catastrophizing or ruminating,
I should have said, I could have done.
All that kind of stuff is the default mode network.
And what the psychedelics in general do is they quiet that.
There's less oxygen to that neurological network.
And so that quiets that down.
And that opens the possibility of other experiences,
more mystical ones, more healing experiences.
And also opens the possibility of new neurological connections
and regrowth of neurological connections.
So they found that after psilocybin, for instance,
that the Hopkins research found that the variable openness was,
there was an increase in openness,
that was when retested a year later, still was true.
And openness is one of those big five personality variables
that are not supposed to change in a lifetime.
So now they're finding, wait a minute, it does change.
It leads to more open novel connections neurologically.
I see. Well, that's very exciting to me.
Yes.
And you brought up the idea of mystical experiences,
which have always been associated with psychedelics.
And of course, we've been referring to Ayahuasca as a sacrament,
which it is officially, formally a sacrament.
I think three different church organizations consider it a sacrament.
But when we talk about mystical experience,
there's also a tradition known as the dark night of the soul.
You couldn't interpret that in a psychological sense
and say, well, you're confronting your own shadow,
but there may be more to it than that.
Right. And some people experience that during a ceremony as well.
And that can come up in as many ways as there are human beings.
But from a shamanic point of view,
some people experience that as a dismemberment,
that they feel that their body is being disintegrated or torn apart in some way.
Some people experience entering into the jaws of a snake, an anaconda,
or eaten by a jaguar.
So there are a lot of ways that people experience that dark night of the soul,
that sense of terrible darkness and pain of being disconnected.
And some scholars, as I recall, consider that a necessary prerequisite
to becoming a shaman is to go through that experience.
You know, I think it's an essential part of it.
I think there's no way around it.
Inevitably, it happens in everybody's spiritual journey.
And I think this is part of what quote I gave you early on
about Anne Shulkin saying therapists have to go through this.
In order to be of any help to someone else
going through this difficult, challenging experience,
we have to be comfortable enough with it ourselves.
Now you have written about having had what one might call a bad trip.
Oh yeah, I would call it a bad trip.
And I learned so much.
And you know, I think a lot of bad trips are very specific to the person.
I mean, there are some that are generic,
like the dismemberment and being eaten by a jaguar.
But the psychological bad trips are like our worst nightmares.
I think there have been some TV shows written about, you know,
if you understand someone's psychology, you know exactly how to torture them.
And that's kind of what a bad trip is.
So I had a very paranoid bad trip where I really felt the shaman were out to get me.
I mean, you know, when you're under the influence
and you feel that the people running the ceremony are intending to harm you,
there is no safe place to go.
There's nothing safe.
I felt the helpers were out to get me.
And I'm not a great warrior.
I think at some point I was so exhausted, feeling that I was going to die,
I just said, you know, to hell with it,
that I kind of collapsed onto a mattress that was conveniently nearby.
I'm not a good fighter.
The next morning I woke up and I looked so awful.
I looked terrible.
It was the opposite of most people wake up the next morning and feel really good.
I looked like I'd been hit by a Mack truck.
And the shaman and the helpers, they all took one look at me,
and they tried to help me.
They did energy healings.
So the very people I thought were out to murder me the night before
were trying to help me and heal me the next morning.
And that was what's called a corrective experience in psychotherapy,
that it was the exact opposite of my paranoid assumption.
And they really spent a lot of time with me the next morning
trying to clear whatever had happened from my energetic system.
And you write about it in some detail, how that related to your childhood.
Oh, it always does.
And we always go back to childhood, absolutely.
Well, if somebody has the experience of
being, let's say, swallowed by an anaconda...
That's an archetype.
I don't know how to relate that to childhood.
Right.
That's an archetype.
That's a different level.
And that's really important that you contrast that.
Because a therapist needs to know,
needs to be able to discern the difference between a childhood trauma
popping up in a ceremony, which is what mine was,
and an archetype, which is what being swallowed by an anaconda
or eaten by a jaguar, that's an archetype.
And it needs to be worked with in a slightly different way.
We're talking, I think, at that level of a spiritual death and rebirth.
Yes, exactly.
And you don't want a therapist making a psychological issue out of that,
which is sort of downgrading that experience.
You want a psychologist to be able to recognize that's in the spiritual realm.
And we want to talk about it in that language, which is different from,
and what did your mother do to you?
You know, it's very different.
I was clearly in the childhood trauma realm.
They're both important.
They're both essential.
And they both need to be worked with in the weeks and months that follow
in terms of not just integration but ongoing psychotherapy.
But you need a therapist who can differentiate those two levels
and work with them differently.
The experience of ayahuasca might be like a dream, for example.
Yes, the visions are very dreamlike.
You know, they call it the television of the jungle.
So in a dream, it's not uncommon to confront monsters, demons, dragons.
And the same thing would be true in a psychedelic or ayahuasca experience.
Right, and some people are very prepared and they jump into the snake's mouth.
You know, that takes a certain kind of courage and ability to navigate,
you know, find your way around an altered state.
Because in a dream reality, it's very often the case that the very thing that you fear,
as soon as you confront it, it loses its scary aspect.
Yes, right.
In Tibetan training, this is called feed the demons.
And it changes everything.
It absolutely does.
It changes the whole context of what is out to destroy you is actually an ally.
I wasn't able to do that that night.
I felt destroyed.
And one never knows, entering an experience,
how it's going to resolve itself.
No, I think most people are nervous before an ayahuasca ceremony.
And this is why.
It can be terrifying.
And you've dealt with people who have had truly terrifying experiences.
Well, you yourself.
Yes, there was one that was very terrifying.
And what I did in the ceremony, in my mind, this was the visual.
I didn't move because I wasn't moving.
I couldn't move at the time.
And that's typical in my experiences as well.
Everybody was kind of in their own little
cocoon, lying down or sitting up on the floor.
Yes, you do your inner work.
So I was not moving.
But in my vision, I ran in back of the shaman where
his whole lineage is behind him that supports him.
These are generations of shaman behind him.
And I sought refuge in his lineage when I was
overwhelmed with fear and trembling, basically.
It was an existential fear and trembling.
And I ran for refuge.
And was very grateful to receive it.
It changed everything.
Now have you, in your many interviews, encountered people who
had a bad experience and were still years later disturbed by it?
No, because people worked through them.
People had one way or another of dealing with it.
So I didn't find one person who said I had a bad
trip, a terrible trip, and I was harmed by it.
I never heard that.
I interviewed people who were harmed by the shaman, who were raped by a shaman.
That's a different thing.
But from their own inner experience, no.
People say it was very challenging, very difficult, and I learned so much.
Now in the early days of psychedelic use, there were instances of suicide.
Linkletter, for example, had a child.
That's a misnomer, actually.
I think she had taken acid six months before.
It was quite a time before.
And she'd already had a history of psychiatric
disturbances, which Linkletter didn't want to talk about.
But you know, I read in the original research they were doing in Maryland, where Stan
Groff originally had the ward where they were using acid with psychiatric inpatients.
Of course, back then, and even in the research protocols these days, they have
a male and a female therapist with everyone taking any of the psychedelics.
So you're never left alone.
You're never alone, and you have the archetype of a parent.
You're never alone with a person of the opposite sex.
And that's also true, or of either sex.
But the next day, that person was also never left alone, which I think
is something that we in this country need to pay more attention to.
In other words, give yourself time after the experience to process.
Right, and if you're not completely together when
everybody else is, somebody should stay with you.
Now, we know that there are harm reduction tents at music festivals and Burning Man.
And the number one rule is, I will stay with you until you're totally okay.
I will not leave you.
There will always be somebody with you.
If I have to take a break, you're never going to be alone.
So it's this enormous reassurance.
In ayahuasca ceremonies, we have to be more sensitive to this.
We have to be sure that nobody wanders off alone, that even after the ceremony is pretty
much over, everybody, as one person put it, everybody's wheels are back on the runway.
Everybody's together.
So the opposite story is someone had carpooled
to an ayahuasca ceremony, carpooled back home.
His friends dropped him off.
He went in the house and he called a taxi to take him to the ER.
He was having a full blown panic attack.
And there was not someone, there was not the structure
in the ceremony for someone to say, are you really okay?
Are you ready to be alone?
And someone to really stay with him.
And I think we have to do better taking care of each other.
We have to build it into the system.
I see.
Well, that's a very good lesson.
Yeah.
That's a very good lesson and I trust that our viewers who
are considering this experience will keep that in mind.
Yes.
Please.
Safety is always a priority.
Set and setting.
We want the setting to be very safe.
Well, Rachel Harris, I'm glad that we're having this conversation.
Normally I like to focus on more upbeat topics.
Label to shadow.
This seemed crucial to me that if we're going to have a series of
interviews about Ayahuasca that we needed to include the shadow side.
I agree.
So thank you very much.
Thank you.
And thank you for being with us.
